definition: Inappropriate or **exaggerated immune response** to an antigen (allergen or self) that causes host tissue damage; classically categorized into **four types (Iâ€“IV)** by the Gellâ€“Coombs system.

images.alt: Diagram of the four types of hypersensitivity: Type I (IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation), Type II (IgG/IgM autoantibodies with complement/ADCC), Type III (immune complex deposition with neutrophil activation), and Type IV (T-cell mediated delayed inflammation).

why_it_matters: Hypersensitivity mechanisms underlie extremely **common conditions** (e.g. hay fever affects ~1 in 10 people worldwide, asthma hundreds of millions, autoimmune diseases ~1 in 12). They can also be **life-threatening** (e.g. anaphylaxis). Recognizing the type of reaction guides diagnosis (allergy testing vs autoantibody assays) and appropriate therapy (e.g. epinephrine for anaphylaxis vs immunosuppression for autoimmunity). These classifications are frequently tested on exams.
how_youll_see_it: ðŸ”´ **Type I (Immediate IgE-mediated)** â€“ Classic **allergic reactions** occurring within minutes of exposure: urticaria (hives), itching, bronchospasm (wheezing), angioedema (swelling), hypotension. Triggers are typically environmental allergens (foods, pollen, insect stings, drugs, latex, etc.), and severe cases present as **anaphylaxis**.

ðŸŸ  **Type II (Cytotoxic IgG/IgM-mediated)** â€“ **Organ-specific** autoimmune or drug-induced reactions. Antibodies target cells or ECM, causing tissue-specific damage. Examples: **hemolytic anemia** or thrombocytopenia (antibody-coated cells destroyed â†’ pallor, jaundice, bleeding), **Goodpasture syndrome** (anti-GBM antibodies â†’ lung hemorrhage + glomerulonephritis with hemoptysis and hematuria), or pemphigus/bullous pemphigoid (antibodies to skin components â†’ blistering).

ðŸŸ¡ **Type III (Immune complex-mediated)** â€“ **Immune complex** deposition causes systemic or localized inflammation, typically with a **delayed onset** (days to weeks after antigen exposure). Presents with **vasculitic** features: e.g. **serum sickness** (fever, rash, arthritis ~1 week after antiserum/drug exposure), **post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis** (hematuria after strep infection), or **lupus** (immune complexes affect joints, kidneys, etc.). Findings often include **complement activation** (potentially low C3/C4) and neutrophil-rich inflammation.

ðŸŸ¢ **Type IV (Delayed T-cell-mediated)** â€“ **Delayed (>48h)** inflammatory reactions mediated by sensitized T lymphocytes, not antibodies. Examples: **contact dermatitis** (e.g. poison ivy or nickel rash developing 1â€“2 days after contact), **tuberculin skin test** (induration peaks ~48â€“72h), **transplant rejection** and **granulomatous inflammation** (like in TB or sarcoidosis) due to Th1-cell activation of macrophages. Often presents with erythema, itching or tissue-specific damage without any detectable antibodies.
problem_solving: **Timing is key:** classify by onset after exposure â€“ **minutes** suggests Type I; **hours** suggests Type II or III; **48â€“72 hours** suggests Type IV.

**Identify the immunologic mechanism:** look for evidence of IgE (**allergy test** positive â†’ Type I), specific autoantibodies (e.g. **Coombs** or anti-tissue antibody â†’ Type II), circulating **immune complexes** (low complement levels, granular immunofluorescence on biopsy â†’ Type III), or T-cell involvement (e.g. contact **patch test** positive â†’ Type IV).

**Diagnostic tests:** Use **skin prick tests** or allergen-specific IgE levels for suspected Type I (immediate) allergies; direct/indirect **Coombs tests** for antibody-mediated cytotoxic reactions (Type II); check complement levels, immune complex assays, or tissue biopsy (immunofluorescence) for immune complex disease (Type III); and perform **patch testing** for contact (Type IV) allergies.

**Mechanistic clues:** Type II reactions tend to be localized to specific tissues (e.g. one organ system affected), whereas Type III often cause **multisystem** or **vasculitic** manifestations due to complexes circulating. Recognize patterns like linear vs granular deposition on immunofluorescence (linear in anti-GBM disease = Type II vs granular in immune complex GN = Type III) to distinguish mechanisms.

differentials.name: Non-IgE (anaphylactoid) reaction
differentials.hint: Clinically similar to anaphylaxis but due to **direct mast cell activation** (no IgE); e.g. contrast dye, opioids.

differentials.name: Hereditary angioedema
differentials.hint: Recurrent **angioedema without urticaria**, caused by **C1 inhibitor deficiency** (bradykinin-mediated); not an IgE allergy.

differentials.name: Stevensâ€“Johnson syndrome
differentials.hint: Severe **delayed drug reaction** with mucosal involvement and skin necrosis (often T-cell mediated Type IV), distinct from immediate IgE-mediated hives.

differentials.name: Irritant contact dermatitis
differentials.hint: Skin inflammation from **chemical irritation** (non-immune); lacks the sensitization and T-cell mediation of allergic contact dermatitis.

tricks: Mnemonic **"ACID"** for Types Iâ€“IV: **A**naphylactic & Atopic (Type I), **C**ytotoxic/antiBody-mediated (Type II), **I**mmune Complex (Type III), **D**elayed (Type IV).
Types **I, II, III** are all **antibody-mediated** (Type I involves IgE; II and III involve IgG/IgM), whereas Type **IV** is the only one mediated by **T cells** (no antibodies involved).

**Type II** can cause **cell destruction** (via complement/phagocytes, e.g. hemolysis) or **cellular dysfunction** without cell death (antibodies acting as agonist or blocker, e.g. **Graves disease** or **myasthenia gravis**). USMLE classifies both as Type II hypersensitivity.

**Type III** reactions often consume **complement** (e.g. low C3/C4 in lupus or serum sickness) due to widespread immune complex activation of the complement cascade. Think immune complexes â†’ **vasculitis** and **neutrophils** (e.g. **post-strep GN**, serum sickness).
exam_appearance: Stung by a bee, within minutes develops wheezing, hives, and hypotension â†’ **Anaphylaxis** (Type I hypersensitivity).
Young adult with hemoptysis and hematuria; renal biopsy shows *linear* IgG deposits along basement membranes â†’ **Goodpasture syndrome** (Type II hypersensitivity).
Patient started on an antithymocyte serum 10 days ago now has fever, urticarial rash, arthralgias, and proteinuria â†’ **Serum sickness** (Type III immune complex reaction).
48 hours after hiking, a patient develops a pruritic blistering rash in streaks on the legs (contact with poison ivy) â†’ **Allergic contact dermatitis** (Type IV delayed hypersensitivity).
treatment: **Type I (Immediate):** Ensure airway; give **epinephrine** IM promptly for anaphylaxis. Adjuncts include **antihistamines** for urticaria, **bronchodilators** for bronchospasm, and **corticosteroids** to reduce late-phase inflammation. Long-term, emphasize **allergen avoidance** and consider **desensitization immunotherapy** for severe recurrent allergies.

**Type II (Cytotoxic):** Remove or treat the offending agent (e.g. stop the drug, treat infection). **Immunosuppressive therapy** is mainstay â€“ typically high-dose **glucocorticoids** to reduce antibody production and inflammation. In severe cases, add **IVIG** (to neutralize pathogenic antibodies) or perform **plasmapheresis** to directly remove antibodies (e.g. in Goodpasture syndrome). Preventive measure: for hemolytic disease of newborn (Rh incompatibility), give RhoGAM to Rhâ€“ mothers.

**Type III (Immune complex):** Address underlying cause (treat infection, discontinue offending drug) and use **immunosuppressants** to dampen ongoing inflammation. **Corticosteroids** are often used (e.g. for lupus nephritis or serum sickness) to reduce immune complex deposition damage. For chronic immune complex diseases like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, steroid-sparing agents (**DMARDs** such as methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, or biologics like TNF inhibitors) are employed.

**Type IV (Delayed):** **Avoid the trigger** allergen or antigen when possible (e.g. known contact allergens). For allergic contact dermatitis, use **topical corticosteroids** to reduce inflammation; more severe reactions may require **systemic steroids** with a taper. In severe T-cell mediated reactions like **Stevensâ€“Johnson syndrome**, hospitalize for supportive care (fluid/electrolyte management, wound care). Chronic Type IV conditions (e.g. transplant rejection, autoimmune) may need potent immunosuppressants (cyclosporine, tacrolimus, etc.).
red_flags: Any signs of **anaphylaxis** (airway swelling, stridor, hypotension) â†’ immediately administer **epinephrine** and secure airway. Do *not* delay, as this is life-threatening.
Painful rash with **mucosal lesions** after a new drug (suspected SJS/TEN) â†’ stop the offending drug and provide urgent hospital care (burn unit or ICU for fluids, wound management).
algorithm: Exposure to potential allergen â†’ **Assess reaction timing and severity** (immediate vs delayed; mild vs anaphylaxis).
If **anaphylaxis** suspected (rapid onset, hypotension, respiratory distress) â†’ **IM epinephrine** *first*, plus airway management and IV fluids as needed.

If not an acute emergency â†’ **Determine likely type**: gather history of timing (minutes vs hours vs days) and perform targeted tests (e.g. skin prick test for IgE, antibody assays or biopsy for immune complexes, patch test for contact).

Classify as Type I, II, III, or IV and **treat accordingly**: e.g. antihistamines/steroids for Type I allergies, immunosuppression or plasmapheresis for antibody-mediated Type II/III, and avoidance + steroids for Type IV. Ensure removal of or avoidance of the triggering antigen in all cases.

cases.stem: A 24â€‘yearâ€‘old man is stung by a wasp while hiking and within minutes develops diffuse hives, wheezing, abdominal cramps, and lightheadedness.
cases.teaching: Classic IgE-mediated **anaphylaxis**: allergen cross-links IgE on mast cells, causing massive histamine and leukotriene release. Presents with rapid-onset hypotension, bronchoconstriction, and urticaria. Immediate treatment is intramuscular epinephrine.

cases.stem: A blood transfusion is started in a patient with anemia, but within an hour he develops fever, flank pain, chest tightness, and oozing from his IV sites. His urine turns red.
cases.answer: Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (Type II hypersensitivity)
cases.teaching: Type II cytotoxic hypersensitivity: pre-formed **IgM** anti-blood group antibodies (ABO mismatch) bind donor RBCs, causing **complement-mediated** hemolysis. Presents with fever, back pain, hemoglobinuria, and DIC. Management includes stopping the transfusion and supportive care (IV fluids, diuretics).

cases.stem: Ten days after receiving antivenom for a snake bite, a 30â€‘yearâ€‘old develops fever, a diffuse urticarial rash, arthralgias, and enlarged lymph nodes. Labs show low C3 complement levels and proteinuria.
cases.teaching: A **Type III** immune complex disease: injected foreign proteins (antivenom) formed soluble **antigenâ€“antibody complexes** that deposited in tissues (skin, joints, kidneys). This causes **complement activation** and inflammation (fever, rash, arthritis, nephritis). It typically arises 1â€“2 weeks after exposure. Treatment is stopping the offending agent and supportive care (antihistamines, NSAIDs, steroids if severe).

cases.stem: A 35â€‘yearâ€‘old female presents with an intensely itchy, blistering rash on her hands and neck. She started using a new nickel-containing jewelry 3 days ago. Patch testing on the skin is positive for nickel.
clues: Itchy blistering rash on contact areas
cases.teaching: **Type IV delayed hypersensitivity**: T-cell mediated reaction to a contact antigen (nickel). Langerhans cells present antigen to Th1 cells, which release cytokines and recruit macrophages â†’ eczematous dermatitis with vesicles. Occurs 1â€“3 days after exposure (no immediate reaction). Treatment is avoidance of the allergen and topical corticosteroids.
